item.title: Fullmetal Alchemist, Vol. 27
item.description:
And so it ends. Fullmetal Alchemist, Vol. 26 was absolutely bonkers, so to say that the final battle actually takes a step back and makes the ending all the more … human, that’s saying something.

But you know what? I think they really pulled off the landing. No idea how or really what in the world was going on there, but it all comes together.

item.title: Fullmetal Alchemist, Vol. 26
item.description:
Ooooh boy. This was really the most absolutely bizarre episode of the whole glorious mess. It’s going full Cthulhu this time around. And it works. I have no idea what’s going on, but it’s glorious!

Oh Father/Dwarf, such power and it still doesn’t understand.

item.title: Fullmetal Alchemist, Vol. 25
item.description:
I find Greed’s storyline absolutely fascinating. Of all the Homunculi, who would have expected that one to be the most likely to change. Perhaps it says something about humanity?

In any case, it’s a crazy story that just keeps getting bigger and crazier. GIANT BATTLES! SOUND EFFECTS! CRAZY THINGS HAPPENING!

item.title: Fullmetal Alchemist, Vol. 24
item.description:
Onward!

Man these books are ramping up for the conclusion. And there are still a handful of volumes left!

item.title: Fullmetal Alchemist, Vol. 23
item.description:
IT CONTINUES!

We have giant battles, contemplations on the ethics of using evil for good means, a showdown with the Flame Alchemist and Envy, The Armstrongs doing strong things with their arms, and A HOUSEWIFE!

item.title: Fullmetal Alchemist, Vol. 22
item.description:
Pride + Gluttony, Ed does what needs doing, and the oh so very creepy zombie attack of Fullmetal Alchemist. Man this story keeps getting crazier and crazier. It’s fascinating to me to see how some loyalties shift from what you believed you knew and some just keep getting better/worse all the while.

Per volume thoughts (potentially spoilery):

item.title: Fullmetal Alchemist, Vol. 21
item.description:
I’m going first

Right in the feels. :(

item.title: Fullmetal Alchemist, Vol. 20
item.description:
Ooooh my. A human traitor, a Homunculus rendered … cute?, the fated meetings of Rose and Winry and Van Hohenheim and his children, a whole manufactored army (because of course) … and the Armstrongs. Oh the Armstrongs. Things just keep escalating step by step. We’re really getting into the endgame now!

Potential spoilers:

item.title: Fullmetal Alchemist, Vol. 19
item.description:
WHOA. MORE BACKSTORY!

WHY AM I YELLING?!

item.title: Fullmetal Alchemist, Vol. 18
item.description:
Hooooly crap. Another Homunculos: Pride. And not at all who I would have expected! Crazy chimera fight (those are still a thing, remember?) and a bit more development and growth from May.

Onwards!

item.title: Fullmetal Alchemist, Vol. 17
item.description:
Man this story is getting crazy. Another Homunculus (Sloth!), a giant transmutation circle under the whole country, more Von Hoenheim backstory, something wicked in the tunnel…

Man this series is good.

item.title: Fullmetal Alchemist, Vol. 16
item.description:
Oh man. A bit of fallout from the war, going north (it’s COLD!), and (re-)meeting another Armstrong. Exciting things and it doesn’t have to even been brainbreakingly weird!

Chapter 62: Beyond the Dream

item.title: Fullmetal Alchemist, Vol. 15
item.description:
Herein, we see the horror of the Ishvalan war. Just how terrifying living weapons of war–taught that the Isvalans are the ‘other’ and deserve to die– can be. Man this chapter hits hard.

It’s interesting to see the research Hiromu Arakawa did for this book.

item.title: Fullmetal Alchemist, Vol. 14
item.description:
Hoo boy. That was yet another crazy volume. I seem to be saying that a lot, but man. Father. Answers. Questions. Alchemy on a whole ‘nother scale. Gross and weird and crazy homunculi.

Onward!

item.title: Fullmetal Alchemist, Vol. 12
item.description:
Man the action of these volumes just keeps ramping up and up. We’re learning more about who all of the Homunculi are, even if not quite getting to why yet. Man there are a lot of people and threads coming together though.

Chapter 46: The Distant Image of Their Backs

item.title: Fullmetal Alchemist, Vol. 13
item.description:
Portals! Father! What is even going ON?!

Man this story is taking a real turn of the very very weird. But in a good way?

item.title: Fullmetal Alchemist, Vol. 11
item.description:
More worldbuilding! More Van Hohenheim! More angst!

These are great.

item.title: Fullmetal Alchemist, Vol. 10
item.description:
The worldbuilding continues to expand. We’re getting some really interesting thoughts on what exactly the difference is between bodies and souls… and what it means to separate them. Also more on how homunculi work and how to finally kill them.

Oy these are crazy.

item.title: Fullmetal Alchemist, Vol. 9
item.description:
Man this story is getting crazy. Both in the worldbuild aspects (we keep learning more about how souls/homunculi/chimeras work) and in a more ‘traditional’ sort: death and PTSD. It’s so well written and drawn. I’m quite enjoying this.

Chapter 34: The Footsteps of a War Comrade

item.title: Fullmetal Alchemist, Vol. 8
item.description:
We’re learning so many more things about the world! And it’s getting bigger and crazier and more wonderful all the time.

30: The Truth Inside the Armor

item.title: Fullmetal Alchemist, Vol. 4
item.description:
I only half remember the anime, which apparently diverges at some point anyways. So it’s a combination of half remembered things and being surprised over and over again. Imagine, being saved by Lust/Envy/Gluttony et al – knowing that there’s far more to them, but not exactly what. It’s crazy.

A few random lovely scenes?

item.title: Fullmetal Alchemist, Vol. 3
item.description:
Oh these are wonderful.

For a while, I was reading an online copy. Turns out that was a fan translation. I’ve seen switched to the real translations from the library, and wow it’s interesting how different the translations can be.

item.title: Fullmetal Alchemist, Vol. 1
item.description: I have never before read Fullmetal Alchemist. Amusingly though, I have seen (one of) the TV versions. It’s been a few years though–I watched it with my now wife before we were even married. So going back and reading it, everything has a strange sort of familiarity.
